repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
This is needed because the type of `result.itemDefaults` is [anonymous](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/8952a89db588db10a9dba16356f9bbd35ca5fabb/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/_meta/protocol.lua#L4776), and using an autogenerated `_anonym` type feels flaky. This is why I manually define `lsp.ItemDefaults` in `completion.lua`, which duplicates the definition :(

Happy to hear for better ideas here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -37,19 +37,49 @@ local function get_completion_word(item)
   return item.label
 end
 
----@param result lsp.CompletionList|lsp.CompletionItem[]
+--- Applies the given defaults to the completion item, modifying it in place.
+---
+--- @param item lsp.CompletionItem
+--- @param defaults lsp.ItemDefaults?
+local function apply_defaults(item, defaults)
+  if not defaults then
+    return
+  end
+
+  item.insertTextFormat = item.insertTextFormat or defaults.insertTextFormat
+  item.insertTextMode = item.insertTextMode or defaults.insertTextMode
+  item.data = item.data or defaults.data
+  if defaults.editRange then
+    local textEdit = item.textEdit or {}
+    item.textEdit = textEdit
+    textEdit.newText = textEdit.newText or item.textEditText or item.insertText
+    if defaults.editRange.start then
+      textEdit.range = textEdit.range or defaults.editRange
+    elseif defaults.editRange.insert then
+      textEdit.insert = defaults.editRange.insert
+      textEdit.replace = defaults.editRange.replace
+    end
+  end
+end
+
+---@param result vim.lsp.CompletionResult
 ---@return lsp.CompletionItem[]
 local function get_items(result)
   if result.items then
+    for _, item in ipairs(result.items) do
+      ---@diagnostic disable-next-line: param-type-mismatch

comment_data.body:
> using an autogenerated `_anonym` type feels flaky.

We could give a better name to the generated "anon" types maybe. I don't see why we would manually define generated types, since we are generating things to avoid that.

comment_data.body: Okay. I don't want to block this PR waiting for the change, so I'll use the anonymous type and update it when we use a better name. WDYT @justinmk?

comment_data.body:
Why the separate file for this? Can this go into _completion?

If we're going to have more public API I think we can then rename that module. Having both _completion and completion shouldn't be necessary(?)

Note that this is indirectly breaking one of the still exposed lsp.utils methods that was recently deprecated. Part of the reason why I suggested to add itemDefaults later and why I wanted to fast track the removal of those methods.

I'm fine pushing ahead with this anyway, but if we do we could at least mention it in the news.txt

See the discussion in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26724#discussion_r1436821011
Ideally we'd get rid of the anonymous types, until we have that I think it's fine to declare them manually

comment_data.body: It's because the work of #27542 will be done in `completion.lua`, and because I feel these are "public" types it made sense to put it here, unless we want to initially put all of the completion work in the private module.
So are you okay with the manual declaration done in this PR, or would you rather use the poorly named generated one (like @justinmk I believe prefers)?

comment_data.body: `extract_completion_items` if called without the default application will likely no longer return usable results.

> unless we want to initially put all of the completion work in the private module.

Either that, or we already rename `_completion` to `completion.lua`.
Not sure how we deal with the omnifunc, because it is also exposed under `vim.lsp.omnifunc`. Could rename it to `_omnifunc`, or deprecate `vim.lsp.omnifunc` in favour of `vim.lsp.completion.omnifunc`. No strong opinion on that.

What I'd like to avoid is having a public `completion.lua` that calls into a private `_completion.lua`.
Yes, I'd be okay with the manual declaration. It's not much effort to remove it once we have the generation improved, and doesn't cause any harm in the meantime as far as I can tell.

comment_data.body: I see. Okay yeah I'm not too worried given the util will be removed soon. I will document that in both the function and in `news.txt`.
Alright I'll move this to `_completion.lua` (we might rename it in #27542). The omnifunc issue might be a larger/longer discussion.

This could also mention the added support for itemDefaults and maybe expand on the implications (lower completion overhead for servers supporting it, and that it could also break 3rd party plugins which don't support it - maybe with a hint how to remove the capability)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,6 +125,10 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
  Returning any truthy value from a callback passed to |nvim_create_autocmd()|
   (rather than just `true`) will delete the autocommand.
 
+ |vim.lsp.util.extract_completion_items()| will no longer return reliable

comment_data.body: Small correction: They're negatively affected if the servers support it but the plugin doesn't.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,6 +125,14 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
  Returning any truthy value from a callback passed to |nvim_create_autocmd()|
   (rather than just `true`) will delete the autocommand.
 
+ |vim.lsp.util.extract_completion_items()| will no longer return reliable
+  results, since it does not apply `itemDefaults` when its input is a
+  `CompletionList`.
+  Moreover, since support for LSP `completionList.itemDefaults` was added,
+  some third party plugins might be negatively impacted because of lack of
+  support by language servers. If necessary, the respective capability can be

comment_regular_data.body: I think this is ready to go ;) @mfussenegger
Do you want to squash your commits?

> Do you want to squash your commits?

Neh, I intentionally separated the changes into those 3 commits. But if you think I was unnecessarily granular I can squishy squash.
I think the doc commit doesn't need to be separate (which triggered the question).
